THOUSANDS OF FEET IN THE AIR
THIS HERE'S A TALE FOR ALL THE
KARA EAVESDROPPING AT THE DOOR WITH A LOOK OF COLD FEAR
A ROW OF ROLL AWAY BAGS
MORE REAL PEOPLE REACTING TO BEING FIRED
A TEAM PHOTO OF A HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL TEAM
BEGINS AS A SERIES OF IMAGES
RYAN AND ALEX KISSING UNDER THE STAIRWELL
INT. SECURITY, EPPLEY AIRFIELD MOMENTS LATER
WHITE COLLAR PEOPLE ARE HANDED PACKETS
A PLANE PULLING BACK ITS GATE AND TAKING OFF
BUSINESSMAN TELLS A JOKE. HIS HANDS GESTURE.
THE MAN LEANS BACK, ARMS CROSSED, WITH A FAR OFF LOOK.
GARDENER DRIVES A RIDER MOWER ACROSS A TINY STRETCH OF GR
RYAN AND ALEX ENTERING A NEW HOTEL ROOM. THEY'RE BECOMING
TURBULENCE. THE BUSINESSMAN TIGHTENS HIS SEAT BELT.
HARD TO GET, FEMALES GET JEALOUS...
THE MAN SPEAKS ABOUT SOMETHING THAT OBVIOUSLY DISTURBS HI
THE SCREEN OF NATALIE'S CELL PHONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kind that shifts between lower income corporate retre and lower income weddings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The few dozen people seem to be visualizing as told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda hard, isn't it? This is what we do to ourselves on a daily basis. We weigh ourselves down until we can't even move. And make no mistake - Moving is living. 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see nodding. People's gears turning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I'm going to set your backpack on fire. What do you want to take out of it? Photos? Photos are for people who can't remember. Drink some gingko and let the photos burn. In fact let everything burn and imagine waking up tomorrow with nothing. (a beat of emphasis) It's kind of exhilarating isn't it? That is how I approach every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A titter through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FEMALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT is looking directly at us.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Do you want the cancer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn to see RYAN looking back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handsome. Anonymous. Right now - Confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want the cancer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan furrows - What the hell is going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flight attendant raises her hand to reveal a CAN OF S

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: The can, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... No. Um, no thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flight attendant moves to the next aisle. Ryan takes beat, then returns to his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two words - Subordinate chic. 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated at a tiny table is RYAN. The Grim Reaper in a suit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a series of REAL PEOPLE react to the news of being fired. They should be non-actors (actual victims of recen layoffs) that can react organically to the news with authenticity. Some are hurt. Others are upset and even abusive. The series concludes with...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... who's on the verge of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREEZE on Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Excellent question. Who the fuck am I? Poor Steve has worked here for seven years.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He's never had a meeting with me before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve in a small meeting.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...or passed me in the hall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve passes a female coworker.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... or told me a story in the break room....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve laughs at a coworker's story. 4.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And that's because I don't work here. I work for another company that lends me out to pussies like Steve's boss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve's BOSS sits at his desk. Subtitle reads - "A Big Pu

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ... who don't have the balls to sack their own employees. And in some cases, for good reason. Because, people do crazy shit when they get fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve wipes off his boss's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve shreds sensitive documents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve pours bleach into the communal coffee pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve loads an assault rifle. He stands up to get a view his coworkers on a coffee break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is trying to hold it together.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And that's where I come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I... do? What could I have done differently here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not an assessment of your productivity. It's important not to personalize this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve scoffs at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan slides Steve a PACKET. 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, I want you to review this packet. Take it seriously. I think you're going to find a lot of answers in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sure it's going be really helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, anybody who ever built an empire, or changed the world, sat where you are now. And it's because they sat there that they were able to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just for a moment, Steve looks hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to need your key card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve begins removing it from his wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the day. Put together your personal things. Talk to your co- workers. Tomorrow, go out and get some exercise. Go for a jog. Give yourself routines and pretty soon you'll find your legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve nods and gets up to leave. Just as he's about to wa out, he stops and turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, how do I get in touch with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. We'll be in touch soon. This is just the beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve nods and exits the room.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'll never see Steve again. 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choreography of Ryan's packing is worthy of Tchaikovs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coat slides off a hanger... A travel toothbrush folds closed like a switchblade... A briefcase clicks onto a ro away bag... A hand flips a light switch without looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan is at the check out desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have your Hilton Honors Card with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan smiles... "Do I?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands it to her, close enough to camera, that we get a nice big close up of it. She runs the card and the screen pops up with information that makes her blush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God... Do you like, live, at the Hilton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan nods in faux modesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan pulls up to one of the spaces marked with the #1 GOL PRESIDENTS CLUB emblem. He hops out and a uniformed man w handheld device begins to punch in the license plate numb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan pulls out his HERTZ PRESIDENTS CLUB CARD and places nice and close to lens so we can see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The card slides through the handheld device and we see th DIGITAL NUMBER increase by a few thousand points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The automated GLASS DOORS slide open. Ryan enters the concourse and takes a deep breath of the temperately controlled air. He has arrived.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is where I live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Subtitles - "Airworld" 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan skips the long lines and steps directly into the AAdvantage Executive Platinum line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glorious close-up of Ryan's AAdvantage Executive Platinum CARD sliding through the AUTOMATED MACHINE. Were it any sexier, we'd hear a moan. Maybe we even do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately, the AIRPORT CLERK registers and perks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasure to see you again, Mr. Bingham.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When I run my card, the system automatically prompts the desk clerk to greet me with this exact statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see it again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasure to see you again, Mr. Bingham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan nods back to the clerk.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Had my status simply been gold or God-forbid, silver. I might have gotten a hello or a smile... Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan continues to hit buttons, swiftly checking in.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Loyalty is earned and rewarded with these small touches. It's these kinds of systemized friendly touches that keep my world in orbit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ticket begins printing. Ryan snaps it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan steps up and observes his line choices. He finds a f Asian businessmen and hops in behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful choreographed ballet of a bag handle collapsing, shoes coming off, a laptop going in a separat tray, wallet and watch sliding into a shoe, a boarding ca sliding into a back pocket... both hands always moving, performing separate actions... It really is gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan enters and presents his ADMIRALS CLUB CARD. It has a hologram. The ADMIRALS CLUB HOSTESS immediately smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRALS CLUB HOSTESS
dialogues.text: Welcome back, Mr. Bingham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan walks past a stack of newspapers on the way to the buffet, the whole time framed by an enormous window overlooking the tarmac.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All the things you probably hate about travelling - The recycled air. The artificial lighting. The digital juice dispensers and mini pizzas stacked to their heat lamps are the warm reminders that I am home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that comment, Ryan slides into a leather club seat. DIGITAL DISPLAY reads: "Thank You For Your Loyalty".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens his briefcase and pulls out his ITINERARY. He sc it. We see a string of flights, car rentals, and stays at Hitons. Then, something makes him frown. He pulls out his cell phone and dials...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan's assistant, Kevin, is not happy to be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan Bingham's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have me in a Dodge Stratus in Kansas City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are completely out of all full sized sedans... 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not the first time) Yes, I reminded them of your remarkable #1 Gold Club status and years in the program. They are moving mountains to see you in a Sebring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough. Any other messages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sister Kara called. Needs to speak urgently about your sister's wedding. I told her you were midair and not even I knew your final destination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you got an invitation to speak at GoalQuest in Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GoalQuest twenty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We push in on an EASEL with a SIGN that features RYAN'S HEADSHOT. Underneath his name, it reads: "What's In Your Backpack?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan delivers his speech with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Every once in a while I do speaking engagements. Motivational kind of stuff. But GoalQuest... We're talking major Tony Robbins shit. 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kevin examines the invitation emblazoned with a big "XX".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got a hologram. They're calling it Dos Equis. That's some pretty major Tony Robbins shit there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk about burying the lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll check in when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, I have Craig Gregory for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... ah, fuck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four words - Store-bought sports memorabilia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the road warrior?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty minutes from boarding into a world of bliss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great numbers out of Phoenix. You know Big Auto is going to drop another 10K this month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No kidding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Christmas came early. Wish I could have you in five places at once. I need you back in Omaha by the end of the week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you needed me everywhere. 11.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG GREGORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We got something big - Game changer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why you ever bring me in. Wherever I go, the money follows. Let me plant seeds, they'll grow to Oaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig checks out a CUTE INTERN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm thinking of planting seeds right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we talking about here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, I took my first crap in two weeks. Hallelujah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me, hanging up on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I love that sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan sits one row behind the bulkhead. Left side. Aisle.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: To know me is to fly with me. I'm the aisle, you're the window - trapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reveal - A man next to Ryan. Some BUSINESSMAN between cit He talks, drink in hand, but we don't hear him.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We start chatting, impersonally at first. Our moderate politics, our sinking opinions on the American service industry. 12.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You recommend a hotel in Tulsa. I tip you off to a rib joint in Fort Worth.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You tell me your best joke. I've heard it before, but listen anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan laughs out loud.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Nothing like turbulence to cement a bond. Soon you're telling me about family.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Your wife just went back to work but you can't intervene because you sure could use the extra paycheck and besides, last June she read some book and woke up one morning a feminist.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And that if your windfall ever came through, you'd quit and spend the rest of your days restoring vintage speedboats. (saying it with him) The water. That's where you belong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their PLANE LANDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the plane begins to taxi to the gate, both Ryan and th Businessman pull out their cards. 13.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We exchange cards and slot them next to countless others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dull bell "dings" to let us know it's safe to stand. and the Businessman get up and open the overheads.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Fast friends aren't my only friends, but my best friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan and the Businessman walk next to each, now completel ignoring each other as if they never shared a word.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sad? Not really. We're a busy bunch. I'm peaceful. I'm in my element here. I suppose I'm a sort of mutation, a new species. I live between the margins of my itineraries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan and the Businessman reach a point that separates - CONNECTING FLIGHTS go left / LONG TERM PARKING goes right

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share an awkward smile with a nod, then head in thei separate directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan is checking out TIES when his cell phone rings. He checks the I.D.- UNAVAILABLE. He weighs it for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: KARA, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: Hi Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan mouths a silent "fuck".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kara is Ryan's sister. Her home overflows with books, pho family collectables, and kid's artwork. 14.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Every family has one person who is the glue. The one who keeps the genealogy in check. That's my sister Kara - The glue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just so happens that Kara is GLUING her daughter's sch project mobile together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Kara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you holding up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just fine. You? The kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missy's outstanding. Matthew made varsity. How's the road?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan exits the store and we realize we are in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan hops onto a PEOPLE MOVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't be better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. So, Ryan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't even want to have to ask you for this, because I know how you are about... doing things for others...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we're coming in on three weeks to go for Julie's wedding and there's something we could really use your help on. 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been sending people these kits so they can print out photos of Julie and Jim on cardboard, and take photos of them in interesting places kind of like that gnome in the French movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's Julie's wedding... and she thinks it's fun. Does it matter why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is Julie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you call her? She thinks you've turned to butter - Disappeared. You're awfully isolated, the way you live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isolated? I'm surrounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your assistant told me you're going to be in Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you get a photo of the cut-out in front of the Luxor Pyramid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That place is a shit hole. No one stays there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Ryan, I'm not asking you to check in. Can you just take a stupid photo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to try my best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thank you for trying your best. 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan sits at one of the couch & table set-ups. He's g over some paperwork. He notices an attractive professiona dressed woman, ALEX, sifting through her purse. She sets pair of car keys with a MAESTRO TAG on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're satisfied with Maestro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're stingy with their miles. I like Hertz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hertz keeps its vehicles too long. If a car's over twenty-thousand miles, I won't drive it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan is intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maestro doesn't instant check out. I like to park and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hertz doesn't guarantee Navigation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny, you don't seem like a girl who needs directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate asking for directions. That's why I get a Nav.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The new outfit, Colonial, isn't bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their kiosk placement is a joke. 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never have available upgrades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's basically a fleet of shit boxes - Don't know how they're still in business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (I love you) I'm Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you going to join me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She breaks into a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty glasses litter the table. Ryan and Alex have taken a couch and have the contents of their wallets spread out All MEMBERSHIP CARDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabs one of Alex's cards) Maplewood Card? How dare you bring that into this palace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hilton offers equal value and better food - But the Maplewood gives out warm cookies at check in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got you with the cookies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a sucker for simulated hospitality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's actually an industry term for that. It's a mixture of faux and homey. It's faumey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex grabs Ryan's AMERICAN CONCIERGE KEY CARD. 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. I've heard about these, but never seen one in person. Is this a...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concierge Key. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graphite. I was pretty excited the day that puppy came in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say. I put up pretty pedestrian numbers. Sixty thou a year, domestic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't patronize me. What's your total?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a personal question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hardly know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show some hubris. Impress me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet it's huge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on... (holds her hands eight

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it this big? (extends a few inches) ... this big? 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just say I've got a number in mind and I haven't hit it yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex smiles, fair enough. Admires the CONCIERGE KEY CARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is pretty fucking sexy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope it doesn't cheapen our relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're two people who get turned on by elite status. We may have to settle for cheap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing cheap about loyalty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex looks into Ryan's eyes and gives him unspoken permis to take her right there and then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan and Alex walk down a curved corridor, suppressing laughter. There's no adult way to go back to somebody's hotel room. Once at the door, Ryan tries his KEY CARD, bu it doesn't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches into his pocket and comes up with five other k cards from recent trips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really have to start throwing these out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries a couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can always use that room with the ice machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan chuckles. He finds the right key and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything is scattered from a marathon Fuck. Ryan and Al are laying on the bed, sprawled out on their backs like murder victims. 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good call on the towel rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I liked how you burritoed me in the sofa cushions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was improvising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad we didn't make it to the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got to do this again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in Newark on the 12th, Madesto on the 13th, Oklahoma City on the 15th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any Southwest? I'm swinging through Albuquerque the week of the 16th?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I'll be in Florida by the 20th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miami?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ft. Lauderdale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They simultaneously type each other into their calendars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should probably go back to my room so I can wake up in my bed. 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that's the lady like thing to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan drops Alex off at her door. She flips the "do not disturb" on her door handle and kisses Ryan good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door closes. Ryan smiles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sprinklers doing their job. One's broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking through the first floor window, we see Ryan doing laps in the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan gets a shoe shine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CLERK swipes Ryan card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAR RETURN CLERK slides Ryan's card through a device.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan SWIPES his FREQUENT FLIER CARD through the automated machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FEMALE DESK ASSISTANT notices the number, looks up at R and has a tiny orgasm right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan looks out the OVAL WINDOW to the landscape of Omaha. 22.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Last year, I spent three hundred twenty two days on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan wheels passed a couple that leaps into each other's

dialogues.speaker: RYAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Which means that I had to spend forty three miserable days at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan steps up to an upscale building with little characte searching for his keys at the bottom of his bag. Finally finds them and opens the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan presses his floor, when a NOSEY NEIGHBOR slides in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't know his name) Hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feels like it's been months, busy man. We missed you at our Summer party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sorry I couldn't be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been trying to get a vote on the new landscaping. Can I e-mail you the plans...? We'd love to get a final tally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. Really. I'll go with the majority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I forget that you even live here. You could probably save money and move into a hotel. 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I looked into it, but the IRS requires a permanent address for employment. Otherwise, they classify you as a vagrant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ding! - Ryan gets off at his floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan walks in and sets his bag down. Reveal - the place i empty... Like empty, empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan opens the fridge - Chinese take out. Pizza box. Bott of Vodka. Takes a whiff of something - not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey neighbor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan turns to find Dianne, a pretty woman just shy of for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hug - It's just intimate enough to know they've viol the rules of sleeping with your neighbors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands over a package) I signed for this while you were gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Hope it wasn't a bother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan opens it and finds the CUT-OUT of his sister Julie a her fiance Jim. It's an eighteen inch card stock photo of hugging Julie from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They seem happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my sister. She's getting married. Haven't met the guy yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of luck. 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share a smile. Then, Dianne goes to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to see you. Feels like a while this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you want to come over tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dianne gets a little uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I kind of started seeing somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's... that's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're having drinks tonight if you want to come over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay... I' think I'll settle in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dianne gives a smile/nod and exits. Ryan take another lon look at the CUT-OUT. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A downtown midsize high rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The company has piled in, standing room only. Assistants interns watch through the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig addresses the group including his own superiors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just thrilled to have everyone under one roof. Welcome home boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple odd looks from road warriors a decade his senior

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG GREGORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know there's are lot of whispering about why we're all here.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG GREGORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Retailers are down twenty percent. Auto industry is in the dump. Housing market doesn't have a heartbeat. This is our moment. It's one of the worst times on record for America... and I don't want to be standing here two years from now, wondering how we missed this window of opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A strangely encouraged response from the group.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG GREGORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, last Summer we received a dynamite young woman by way of Cornell. She challenged us with some big ideas. My first reaction was, who does this kid think she is? But when I started to give a listen, I was pretty knocked out. So now, with a little peek into our future - Natalie Keener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's one word I want to leave you with today, it's this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie clicks on her POWER POINT PRESENTATION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone including Ryan attempts to pronounce it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glocal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POWER POINT SLIDE: "GLOBAL ---> LOCAL"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our global must become local.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POWER POINT SLIDE: A slide shows PEOPLE X 250.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This company keeps twenty three people on the road, at least two hundred fifty days a year. It's expensive and it's inefficient. When I came to Craig three months ago with this, he told me, and quite astutely - it's only a problem if you have a solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, today I stand before you with jus that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns around and fires up her monitor. Sitting in a v conference session is a young man in a suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all know Ned in reception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various people say hello to Ned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today, I'm going to fire Ned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Ned. I'm sure H.R. will hire you back this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned smiles. People chuckle in the conference room. One gu jokes "Don't count on it."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned could be any employee in any one of our client's locations worldwide. Strategy packets would be shipped in advance. Ned would be given a seat and find one of our transition specialists waiting for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie turns to the monitor and proceeds to fire Ned. It a pretty dry process and lacks Ryan's charm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Laskin, the reason we're having this conversation today is your position is no longer available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from a script) I don't understand. I'm fired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing the words "You've been let go" is never easy. Change is always scary. But consider the following - (using Ryan's line) Anybody who ever built an empire, or changed the world, sat where you are now. And it's because they sat there that they were able to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my fucking line. 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what happens now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the first step of a process that will end with you in a new job that fulfills you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but, how does it work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to take that packet in front of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned picks up the packet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Review it. All the answers you're looking for are inside. Start filling out the necessary information and before you know it, you'll be on your way to new opportunities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned starts to peruse the packet with fake interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Ned, I'm going to need you to go back to your desk and start putting together your things. As a favor to me, I'd appreciate it if you didn't spread the news just yet. Panic doesn't help anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a good day, Mr. Laskin and good luck with your future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ned gets up and goes to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it up for Ned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People clap and tease him a little. 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POWER POINT: An animation of one monitor becoming multipl monitors, all tied into a central switch board in the mid of a map of the country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can start the morning in Boston, stop in Dallas over lunch and finish the day in San Francisco. All for the price of a T1 line. Our inflated travel budget is eviscerated by eighty-five percent... And most importantly to you guys on the road... No more Christmases in a hotel in Tulsa... No more hours lost to weather delays... You get to come home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan is in a state of silent panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan enters and stops short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me you're not taking this seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's why we brought the entire company in from the road - Because we're not taking this seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't make any sense. It's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... completely impersonal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who am I even talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a methodology to what I do. A reason why it works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan, Coke and IBM have been doing it for years. Just like anything, there's a few months of transition, but everyone settles in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you taking off the road? 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't get it. You're grounded, Ryan. Everyone is. It's done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, what we do here is brutal and leaves people devastated, but there's a dignity to the way I do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stabbing people in the chest instead of the back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig's door opens and Natalie pops her head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig goes to wave her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, why don't you come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie is confused but takes the chair next to Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great job in there, Nat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. How's everyone taking it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie and Ryan hold a look for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I appreciate your... zeal. And you have some good ideas. But you know nothing of the realities of my job. Sure, you can set up an iChat... but you don't know how people think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I minored in psychology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay kiddo, fire me. 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan, stop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's going to be doing this on a regular basis. You don't want to know if she can fire somebody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just fired Ned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dog could fire Ned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, I got this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan and Natalie turn to face each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bingham, I regret to inform you that your position is no longer available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Miss Keener and I'm here today to discuss your future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My future? I don't know you. The only person who can fire me is Craig Gregory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gregory hired me to handle this for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handle what? Handle me? Mr. Gregory hired me and he's the only one who can fire me. I'm going to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan gets up. Natalie gets up too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bingham... 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't follow me... You're on a computer screen. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try again. Fire me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, you didn't. Now, fire me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it, Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bingham, I'm here today to inform you that your position is no longer available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never say fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaks the moment) This is a mythical situation. How could I possibly know why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never know why. Why doesn't matter. 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back on track) It's important not to focus on the "why" and rather to spend your energy thinking about your future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to spend my energy on suing you if you don't give me a reason that you're firing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Bingham, the reason is not important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so you're firing me without grounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I really have a lawsuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan, I think we know what you're trying to say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still in character) Don't take this personally, Mr. Bingham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally? (quiet and calm) This is the most personal situation you will ever enter. So before you try to revolutionize my business, I'd like to know that you actually know my business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan is staring out his window watching a plane take flig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell-of-a-way to welcome her to the team. 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I the only one who sees that by automating our own business, we're making ourselves irrelevant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frankly...) No... We're making you irrelevant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan shoots a look.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG GREGORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, don't blame me. Blame fuel costs. Blame insurance premiums. Blame technology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch yourself, Ryan. You're too young to be a dinosaur...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not... I'm not a dinosaur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to show her the ropes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I know about what happens around here? Have Ferguson do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat as Ryan registers what Craig means: The Road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you seem pretty confident that this girl doesn't know what she's doing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. I just don't think a MySpace page qualifies you to rewire an entire company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Well, here's your chance. Show her the magic. Take her through the paces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a fucking tour guide. 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig cups one of his hands and places a FOLDED POST-IT between his fingers like a ship's sail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: his hand) This is the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craig raises his other finger far away.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG GREGORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (re: his finger) This is you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat of Ryan taking in this ridiculous illustration.

dialogues.speaker: CRAIG GREGORY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you want to be in the boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan, we're ringing the bell. Rounding everybody up. If you want to stay out there a little longer, you can. But you're not going to be on your own. (begins to leave) Let me know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan churns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan is packing his ROLL-AWAY BAG. It is practiced and systematic. He's just about finished, when he notices the OUT of his sister's engagement photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tries placing it in the open bag, but it is immediatel clear that the photo is two inches to long. He tries putt it on an angle, but that doesn't help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan centers the cut-out again and tries to ZIP around it but he can't get the zipper around the HEADS of the photo For a moment, it almost seems like he's assaulting their head with the zipper handle. Doesn't help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment of silent frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being pulled through an airport. The little heads of Ryan sister and her fiance are poking out the top of the bag. two zippers have been closed on either side of them as th they were tiny passengers peeking out the sunroof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan cuts right through the crowd, wheeling his carry-on towards the automatic check-in machines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan stops when he notices NATALIE saying goodbye to her BOYFRIEND - a kind of Hollister looking guy in his mid- twenties. He's not thrilled by the public affection. Afte beat, they break and he exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie sees Ryan and starts dragging her LARGE SUITCASE towards him. The SCRAPING against the terrazzo sends a sh up Ryan's spine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She arrives and sets the heavy bag down with a CLUNK. Rya stares at her travel case for a beat then up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan pulls one out and tests the action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really like my luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what it is. Luggage. (off of Natalie's look) You know how much time you lose by checking in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, maybe five minutes waiting for... 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty five minutes per flight. I travel two hundred seventy days a year. That makes one hundred fifty seven hours... That's Seven Days. (points to her luggage) You ready to throw away a whole week on that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie is attempting to repack her new bag in the middle the airport. Ryan helps by throwing a couple things out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan spots various "bad lines", then sees a group of Asia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingo. Asians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan starts walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they pass the first line - A FAMILY OF SIX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never get behind people travelling with infants. I've never seen a stroller collapse in less than twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second Line - AN ELDERLY COUPLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old people are worse. Their bodies are littered with hidden metal and they never seem to appreciate how little time they have left on Earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third Line - A COUPLE MIDDLE EASTERN GUYS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five words. Randomly selected for additional screening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the fourth line behind the Asians. 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asians. They're light packers, treasure efficiency, and have a thing for slip-on shoes. God love'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's racist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm like my mother. I stereotype. It's faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan is just fastening his belt, having just gone through security, when we hear a beeping go off. Natalie is tryin find the metal on her body that has set off the machine. has forgotten to take her laptop out of her bag. It's a m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan is sketching a theoretical book cover for "The Backback". Natalie is working on an Excel Document on her laptop - She's a loud tapper... Hitting the keys with vio strokes. It draws Ryan's attention and a raised eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you upset at your laptop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fats Domino had a lighter touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I type with purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you working on so furiously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm building a work flow of firing techniques. Questions & responses. Actions & reactions. A script that works kind of like a tributary, taking you through the steps of firing someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it for? 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theoretically, you could put it in the hands of anybody and they could be downsizing immediately. All they have to do is follow the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie, what is it, you think we do here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We prepare the newly unemployed for the emotional and physical hurdles of job hunting while... Minimizing potential legal blowback?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we're selling. But it's not what we're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, what are we doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our job is to make limbo tolerable - To ferry wounded souls across the river of dread and humiliation to the point at which hope's bright shore is dimly visible...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then to stop the boat, shove'em in the water, and make them swim while we row back to the palace of their banishment to present the employers with our bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was really impressive. You rehearse that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie smiles and goes back to her work. Ryan goes to sa something, but holds back for now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan zips through the wandering types as Natalie tries to keep up. Ryan's phone rings. He sees the caller ID. Smile

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to grab this. I'll meet you at the rental lot. 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie nods and keeps moving. Ryan picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I was hoping I'd hear from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is on her cell phone as a junior behind her folds a portable projector screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in Hotlanta. I need a rib joint recommend bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fat Matt's. Bring a bib.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan turns into an elevator well to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I didn't know what was appropriate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex stops. She moves to a quieter place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan, I'm not some waitress you banged in a snow storm. The word "Appropriate" has no place in our collective vocabulary. I'm the woman you don't have to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This sounds like a trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time you're worried about manners - Don't. If you want to call - Call. Just think of me as yourself... only with a vagina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan lights up... This woman fucking rocks. Then recovers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When am I going to see you? 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm out of Hartsfield, into IAD, then a connection at ORD into SDF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is your layover in O'Hare? They've got multiples into SDF... Think you could push?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can push.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan and Natalie ride, briefcases in hand. Natalie is swa back and forth. Ryan notices. Is she nervous? Excited?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ding - The elevator door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan and Natalie enter the door to find a reception desk an empty floor. Scattered telephones sit on the ground wh desks used to be. A few desks in one corner are still man

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie tries not to show: It's all becoming very real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to desk girl) Ryan Bingham, from CTC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The desk girl looks up from her work. She knows who they

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan and Natalie pass rows of cubicles. Heads begin to po to see their arrival. Natalie accidentally makes eye cont with one guy, then quickly shifts her gaze forward. 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan and Natalie sit next to each other at a polyurethane conference table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you have to do today is watch and listen. When I talk about the strategy packet. You hand them one of these...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan points to a stack of packets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever find it strange that termination comes with a packet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything important in life comes with a packet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SERIES OF REAL PEOPLE sit down across from Ryan and Nat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming by. As you're probably well aware, this is a tough economic climate and your company is not immune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REAL PEOPLE tighten up as they begin to catch on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While I wish I was here with better news, the reason you and I are meeting is this is your final week of employment here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REAL PEOPLE blame all sorts of people and situations that they personally hold responsible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a time to look for blame. Your position simply no longer exists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REAL PEOPLE respond further. Some are enraged. Some are polite. One is even grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand why you are saying these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's perfectly natural to feel this way. I want you to take the next week to explore this strategy packet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan nods to Natalie who we now see begrudgingly HANDING PACKETS to all of the REAL PEOPLE we've already met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fill out the skill set work sheet... Use the hopes and dreams diagram... And the tree of aspirations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE the "TREE OF ASPIRATIONS" sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The answers are all in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see more packets getting handed out as Ryan repeats...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The answers are all in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The answers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The answers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... are-all-in-there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you suggest I tell them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOB. Dry red eyes from tears of rage stare down the lens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie can't hold back any longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you're underestimating the positive effect your career transition may have on your children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan looks at Natalie like she's out of her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Positive effect? 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, tests have shown that children under moderate trauma have a tendency to apply themselves academically as a method of coping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go fuck yourself. That's what my kids'll think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie shrinks. Ryan immediately covers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your children's admiration is important to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I doubt they ever admired you, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks up shocked and pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey asshole, aren't you here to console me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a shrink, Bob. I'm a wake up call. You know why kids love athletes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they screw lingerie models.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's why we love athletes. Kids love them because they follow their dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well I can't dunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can cook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie looks to Ryan - Where is he going with this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan picks up Bob's resume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your resume says you minored in French Culinary Arts. Most students work the frier at KFC. You bussed tables at Il Picatorre to support yourself. Then you got out of college and started working here. (looks up at Bob) How much did they first pay you to give up on your dreams?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty seven thousand a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At what point were you going to stop and go back to what made you happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob simply shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe in fate, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You know, the mysterious ways in which we wind up doing the things we were meant to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I met my wife at a gas station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. Well, I think fate is telling you to do something, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob looks up and meets eyes with Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see guys who work for the same company their entire lives. Clock in. Clock out. Never a moment of happiness. (pauses for effect) Not everyone gets this kind of opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chance for rebirth. If not for yourself... Do it for your kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob's eyes begin to water again. He's a changed man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan shoots Natalie a look - Hand over the packet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie jumps to attention and hands Bob a packet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a BUSINESS WOMAN waiting in the regular line. Rya walks right past her and gets into the ELITE LINE. They a now both first in their respective lines for the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman looks over at Ryan and sighs. Natalie holds bac confused by Ryan's actions and wanting to avoid confronta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DESK CLERK frees up and gestures for Ryan to step forward. Ryan begins wheeling his bag forward. Meanwhile, woman lifts her hand in outrage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been waiting ten minutes. He just waltzes in and gets to cut in line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We reserve priority assistance for our Hilton Honors members.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan grabs a BROCHURE for ELITE MEMBERSHIP off the desk a hands it to the business woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should look into it - The promotions are great...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman bats it out of Ryan's hand onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan looks back at the desk clerk and smiles. The desk cl swipes his card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan's DIGITAL NUMBER bumps up another thousand points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie is washing her hands, when she stops to look at herself in the mirror. 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a beat, she hears someone CRYING in one of the stal She goes to see if the woman is okay, then stops herself Maybe I fired her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs a paper towel, dries off her hands, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie sits back down at the table a little visibly shak

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then, their food arrives... And there's a lot of foo Natalie's eyes move back and forth trying to figure out w there seems to be three main courses and a bunch of sides

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungry, much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our expense account allots for forty dollars each on dinner. I plan on grabbing every mile I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you got to fill me in on this mile business. What's that all about? Are you talking like frequent flier miles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan gives Natalie a look - Is she ready for this informa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your really want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dying to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't spend a nickel, if I can help it, unless it somehow profits my mileage account. I'm not talking hotel rooms and rental cars either, but internet services, cell phone, music downloads, teleflorists. The works. I shop them according to the miles they pay and I pit them against each other for the most value. 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what are you saving up for? Hawaii? South of France?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not like that... The miles are the goal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it? You're saving to save?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just say I've got a number in mind and haven't hit it yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Seems a little abstract. What's your target?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a secret target?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ten million miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. Isn't ten million just a number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pi is just a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we all need a hobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan looks back at Natalie - Hobby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hey, I didn't mean to belittle your collection. I get it. Sounds cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be the seventh person to do it. More people have walked on the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they give you a parade or something? 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lifetime Exec Platinum status. You get to meet the Chief Pilot, Maynard Finch. And... They put your name on the side of a plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men get such a hard-on from putting their name on stuff... You guys don't grow up - You just need to pee on everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, who's stereotyping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fear of mortality. It's like Yes, you're going to die one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why do you suppose that's singular to men?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably cause you can't have babies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan can't help but laugh a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I had that many miles, I'd just show up at the airport, look up at one of those big destination boards, pick a place and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This idea sinks in for a second with both of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan is laying in bed wearing a Hilton bathrobe. He's reviewing his sister's wedding invite when his BLACKBERRY BUZZES on the night stand. He reaches over to check it. I a text message:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex: "Can't fall asleep."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan types back:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan: "Me too. Just laying here."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is in a t-shirt, lying in bed. She types away at her BLACKBERRY and presses SEND.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan's BLACKBERRY BUZZES again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex: "You should rub one out."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Types back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan: "Only fair if you do too."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACKBERRY BUZZES again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex: "Way ahead of you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan: "Call me next time so I can listen."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex: ";) Have sweet dreams about me."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan smiles. He stares at the message for a second, then the blackberry down and turns off the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie is standing with a camera in her hands, giving directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left, left, left, left... one more inch... and stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reveal: Ryan is placing the CUT-OUT of Julie and Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera POV makes it look like Julie and Jim are stand in front of St. Louis International Airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister is cooky. She thinks this is charming... Like the gnome thing. 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean... why would your sister want a fake photo in front of the St. Louis Airport?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She should be so lucky to visit Lambert Field. The Wright Brothers flew through there... (points out the conical

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The domed main terminal was the first of its kind. A precursor to everything from JFK to DeGualle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Pretty sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie takes the photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why she wants dozens of reminders of all the places she hasn't been is beyond me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sure she's going to be crushed for having missed this airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look - Before Lindbergh could cross the Atlantic, he took off from one of those runways... Ever wondered why they call it the Spirit of St. Louis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan goes to say something, but Natalie is already gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan and Natalie sit stoically as a YOUNG ASIAN GUY rants about why they are idiots to fire him.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG ASIAN GUY
dialogues.text: ... And another thing...? You know how fucked this place is without me? You know how fucked this place is without me? Fucked in the ass, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG ASIAN GUY (cont'd) I am the one thing preventing this place from being totally fucked in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young asian guy snaps up one of the PACKETS and leave slamming the door behind himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes, they just need to vent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, for the love of God, can I fire the next one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan gives it some thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A professional African-American woman wearing a smart sui sits down at the conference table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to be fired, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here to talk about your future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to sugar coat it. I get the drill. What are they offering?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the packet you'll find a clearly worked out severance package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the bullet points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three months pay. Six months medical. A full year of placement services through our company, CTC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Placement services? How generous. 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commonly, it takes one month of searching for every ten thousand dollars you expect to earn in salary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I could be looking for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not necessarily...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't sweat it. I'm pretty confident about my plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Can you tell me? Is high tide in the morning or the evening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's this beautiful bridge by my apartment. I need to figure out what time to jump off it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie begins to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie bursts out the doors and sits on a bench. She's freaked out. Ryan is five steps behind her. He puts a han her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People say these things all the time. It comes with the trade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. People are always saying crazy stuff. They get worked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was so calm. 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not quite sure) I think that's a good sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they don't actually ever do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... it's just talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know? Do you follow up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, no, nothing good can come of that, but I don't think you should worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie is clearly still worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the job. Taking people at their most fragile moment and setting them adrift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking out the window at the passing landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the pastures and roads, we see GRAPHIC WHITE LINES A NUMBERS denoting each mile as they click by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan tears a page out of AMERICAN WAY MAGAZINE outlining their mileage program and hands it to Natalie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan turns a corner to find Natalie talking to her comput screen with headphones on. 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's having an iChat with someone, but we only hear her of the conversation. Ryan decides to listen in for a seco

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back soon. Not really sure how long this whole exercise is supposed to last. He's fine... It's hard for these guys to accept change, you know. (listens, rolls eyes) I... I'm not even going to answer that... No, I can't even think of him that way... He's old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan frowns. Checks a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 757 touches down on the runway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RYAN'S HEADSHOT - sitting on an EASLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan stands before a similar crowd as the opening of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. This is where it gets a little difficult, but stay with me. You have a new backpack... but this time, I want you to fill it with people. Start with casual acquaintances, people around the office, friends of friends and work your way to the people you trust with your most intimate secrets. Now move into family members - cousins, aunts, and uncles. Get your sisters and your brothers and you parents. Get them all in that backpack. And finally your husband or wife or boyfriend or girlfriend. Get them in their too. 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A titter through the crowd. For the first time, we see Natalie near the side, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'm not going to ask you to light it on fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feel the weight of that bag. Make no mistake, your relationships are the heaviest components of your life. Feel the straps cutting into your shoulders. All those negotiations and arguments and secrets and compromises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan lets the weight sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now set that bag down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can feel the relief in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to carry all that weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noticeable agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some animals were meant to carry each other. To live symbiotically over a lifetime. Star-crossed lovers. Monogamous swans. We are not one of those animals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan focuses towards his conclusion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slower we move, the faster we die. We are not swans. We're sharks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan has finished his session and is talking to eager stragglers. Ryan accepts a business card and elaborates o one of his theories. 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, down the hall, Natalie is finishing a phone ca She looks shell shocked. She closes her phone and pockets in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN AMERICAN AIRLINES PLANE touches down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're following a HILTON SHUTTLE down a street of PALM TR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natalie and Ryan ride back to the airport. We catch them conversation as Natalie drills Ryan on his theory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan smiles to the few other riders as if apologizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never want to get married? Never want kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that so bizarre?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
